The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This item presents a review, update and identification of the next steps in the joint collaborative work between the Milpitas Unified School District and the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District governing boards.  In particular, this report presents the progress and current status of lead staff from both institutions in the establishment of what is now known as the 21st Century Joint Education Services Center.  In prior meetings staff provided historical background, facilitated the signing of a joint Memorandum of Understanding, reviewed implementation steps related to site selection and completion of an Environmental Impact Report (EIR).  In addition, staff also provided a timeline that included the development and issuance of an educational needs assessment survey, the educational programming and design based on the findings of that survey and the emerging principles to guide the design and construction of  the  Center.
	 
This presentation has as its primary focus a review of the survey findings, the proposed educational programming and the principles that will guide the design and construction of the new facility culminating in estimated occupancy dates.

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, “the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition, or purchase order … [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment … and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase.” The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a piggybackable contract between the FCCC and Konica Minolta Business Solutions without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. FCCC is the official foundation of the California Community Colleges’ Board of Governors and Chancellor’s Office that was established as an auxiliary organization of the California Community Colleges pursuant to California Education Code Sections 72670-72682.
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, a Foundation for California Community Colleges board announcement dated June 11, 2013 awarding the piggybackable contract to Konica Minolta Business Solutions, and a proposal from Konica Minolta Business Solutions for $133,150.67.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to ‘piggyback’ on the Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) contract with Konica Minolta Business Solutions for the Evergreen Valley College Library.

items.item_details: San Jose City College has participated in the Calteach Initiative (Aurora Grant) since Spring 2007 until Fall 2012.  The purpose of the Aurora Grant was to encourage high level students majoring in STEM fields to consider a career in science or math education in the K-12 education system.  San Jose City College students who were enrolled in high level math and science classes took the transferable course, Education 14-Field Experience in Math and Science.  San Jose City College students assisted teachers at Franklin-McKinley School District in San Jose.  Students who successfully completed the course were paid a stipend to offset the expenses in commuting to the schools.  San Jose City College no longer offers the Education 14 class.  The balance of the funds will be distributed among the participating schools.

items.item_details:
At the Board Meetings held March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012, the Program Management team and District legal counsel presented information and details regarding the Lease/Leaseback (LLB) project delivery method.  Subsequently, on July 10, 2012 the Board approved this method for two Measure G-2010 projects, including this project.
	 
A Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Lease/Leaseback Construction Services was issued on August 6, 2012.  Twelve Statements of Qualifications (SOQ’s) were received.  A selection Committee comprised of District and College faculty and staff reviewed, scored and ranked the SOQ’s.  They then pre-qualified the five highest ranked firms, and conducted interviews with each firm.  Each firm then received a score from the committee based on their presentations.  Following the interviews the five pre-qualified firms then submitted sealed proposals for lump sum pre-construction services and fee percentages for construction services.
	 
Based on the combination of points awarded and fee proposal, Kitchell CEM, Inc. was determined to be the successful firm by providing the “best value” to the District.  Their proposal includes a fixed fee for pre-construction services as well as construction service fees and percentages to be applied to the Guaranteed Maximum Price.  
	 
On January 28th 2014 Kitchell CEM, Inc. received bids for Phase 1 of the project from 10 subcontractors; these bids were reviewed by Kitchell and then reviewed with District purchasing on January 31st 2014.  The successful bids combined with Kitchell’s construction service fees and percentages resulted in a Guaranteed Maximum Price of $4,914,192.00 for this project.

At its August 13, 2013 meeting the Board approved a Project Assignment Amendment with Sandis to provide design services for the Campus Water Service Replacement Project at Evergreen Valley College.  Since that time Sandis has met with College and Maintenance staff and Grounds personnel to develop the project scope.  The project consists of replacing approximately 870 lineal feet of existing water main that runs through the campus, installation of new water valves in various locations and replacement of the existing Gullo grease interceptor.
	 
On February 26, 2014 bids were received for the project.  The bid package was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers and published at 20 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors including small and disadvantaged businesses.  
	 
S&H Construction, Inc.          $488,000
Cratus Inc.                              $544,200
KMS                                       $588,799
Northern Underground           $811,966
	 
Based on the evaluation of the bids received, S&H Construction Inc., a Small Business Enterprise from Fremont, CA is determined to be the lowest responsible bidder in the amount of $488,000.  The Engineer’s estimate for the project is $450,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to S&H Construction, Inc. in the amount of $488,000 for the Evergreen Valley College Campus Water Service Replacement Project.

items.item_details:
An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District on November 2, 2004 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $185,000,000 (the “2004 Measure G”).  The District now desires to issue its third series of bonds (the Series C Bonds) under 2004 Measure G in an aggregate principal amount not-to-exceed $31,605,000 (the “Bonds”).  This amount represents substantially all of the remaining unissued bonds of the 2004 Measure G.  The Bonds are being authorized for sale for the purpose of providing funds to (i) to finance the costs of renovating, acquiring, constructing, repairing and equipping of District buildings and other facilities and (ii) pay the costs of issuing the Bonds.
	 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Bonds, specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Bonds, and approves the form of Purchase Contract, Continuing Disclosure Certificate, and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Bonds to be issued ($31,605,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (0.5%) with respect to the Bonds, and authorizes the Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to RBC Capital Markets, LLC and Piper Jaffray & Co. (together, the “Underwriters”).  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of current interest bonds only.
	 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriters will agree to buy the Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (“POS”) is the offering document describing the Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to among other things (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Bonds (the tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d) Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds, are obligated to procure from a bond issuer a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data with respect to the District” through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (which is the federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligation issuances).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	 
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Bonds.

items.item_details:
An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District on November 2, 2010 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $268,000,000 (the “2010 Measure G”).  The District now desires to issue its third series of bonds (the Series C Bonds) under the 2010 Measure G in an aggregate principal amount not-to-exceed $120,000,000 (the “Bonds”).  The Bonds are being authorized for sale for the purpose of providing funds to (i) to finance the costs of renovating, acquiring, constructing, repairing and equipping of District buildings and other facilities and (ii) pay the costs of issuing the Bonds.
	 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Bonds, specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Bonds, and approves the form of Purchase Contract, Continuing Disclosure Certificate, and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Bonds to be issued ($120,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (0.5%) with respect to the Bonds, and authorizes the Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to RBC Capital Markets, LLC and Piper Jaffray & Co. (together, the “Underwriters”).  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of current interest bonds only.
	 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriters will agree to buy the Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (“POS”) is the offering document describing the Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to among other things (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Bonds (the tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d) Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds, are obligated to procure from a bond issuer a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data with respect to the District” through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (which is the federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligation issuances).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	 
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Bonds.

An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (the “District”) on March 2, 2004 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $185,000,000 (the “2004 Authorization”).  The District has previously caused the issuance of bonds under the 2004 Authorization, including $55,391,474 of its General Obligation Bonds, Election of 2004, Series A (the “2004 Series A Bonds”).  
The District has also previously caused the issuance of its $55,930,994.55 2004 General Obligation Refunding Bonds, Series A (the “2004 Refunding Series A Bonds”) and $34,470,000 2004 General Obligation Refunding Bonds, Series C (2010 Crossover) (the “2004 Refunding Series C Bonds,” and together with the 2004 Series A Bonds and 2004 Refunding Series A Bonds, the “Prior Bonds”). 
	 
The District now desires to refinance portions of the outstanding Prior Bonds (so refunded, the “Refunded Bonds”) through the issuance of general obligation refunding bonds (the “Refunding Bonds”) in an aggregate principal amount of not-to-exceed $140,000,000.  All benefits from the refunding will be delivered to the property owners in the District.  The final maturity of the Refunding Bonds will not be later than the maturity dates of the Refunded Bonds.
	 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Refunding Bonds, in one or more series of federally taxable or federally tax-exempt bonds.  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of the Refunding Bonds, specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Refunding Bonds, and approves the form of Purchase Contract, Continuing Disclosure Certificate, Escrow Agreement and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Refunding Bonds to be issued ($140,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (0.5%) with respect to the Refunding Bonds, and authorizes the Refunding Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to RBC Capital Markets, LLC and Piper Jaffray & Co. (together, the “Underwriters”).  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of current interest bonds only.
	 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriters will agree to buy the Refunding Bonds from the District.  All of the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (“POS”) is the offering document describing the Refunding Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to, among other things, (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Refunding Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Refunding Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Refunding Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Refunding Bonds (the tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Refunding Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Refunding Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d) Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds, are obligated to procure from a bond issuer a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data with respect to the District” through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (which is the federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligation issuances).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Refunding Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years. 
	 
(e)        Escrow Agreement.  Pursuant to the Escrow Agreement, proceeds from the sale of the Refunding Bonds in an amount sufficient to redeem the outstanding Refunded Bonds will be deposited in an escrow fund (the “Escrow Fund”) held by U.S. Bank National Association (acting as “Escrow Agent”).  The monies in the Escrow Fund will be used by the Escrow Agent to (i) refund a portion of the outstanding 2004 Series A Bonds on or about September 1, 2015, (ii) refund a portion of the outstanding 2004 Refunding Series A Bonds on or about September 1, 2014, and (iii) refund a portion of the outstanding 2004 Refunding Series C Bonds on or about September 1, 2014.  As a result of the deposit and application of funds so provided in the Escrow Agreement, the Refunded Bonds will be defeased and the obligation of Santa Clara County to levy ad valorem taxes for payment of the Refunded Bonds will cease.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Refunding Bonds.

The Accrediting Commission of Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) placed City College of San Francisco (CCSF) on "show cause," the highest level of sanction and recently made the decision to revoke the institutionâs accreditation status as of July, 2014.  
	 
The enclosed resolution, for approval consideration, was written to support CCSF. It reiterates backing for a 2-year bill (AB 1199 introduced by Assemblymember Fong) and supported last year by the SJECCD Board of Trustees and also articulates support for SB 965 introduced March 10, 2014, by Senator Mark Leno, which, if passed, would stabilize funding for City College of San Francisco by providing a safety net over the next 4 years as the institution works to restore student enrollment and remain accredited. 
	 
The resolution also urges elected officials to do everything in their power to ensure that City College of San Francisco remains open so that it can continue to serve our most vulnerable communities.

Over the years various manufactured materials and products have been incorporated into the District’s facilities.  Cost savings and efficiencies are realized by minimizing the quantity of parts inventoried by the District Maintenance Department and contracts with service companies, as well as training or tools needed to maintain multiple brands of products.  The California Public Contract Code acknowledges these savings and efficiencies in Section 3400 (c) 2, by allowing the designation of materials, products, things or services by specific brand or trade name in Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals for certain purposes.  These include the desire or need to match other products in use on a completed campus facility or on a facility being completed.
	 
The Public Contract Code Section 3400 (c) 1 also allows for the specific brand or trade name be used if executing a field test or experiment in order to determine a product’s suitability for future use.  Recently the Evergreen Valley College Facilities and Safety Committee selected a specific brand of LED exterior light fixtures (listed in the table below) to be installed and tested to establish a campus-wide standard for safe, energy efficient and attractive pole-mounted exterior fixtures presenting a cohesive and complementary appearance with other architectural elements on campus.  If these light fixtures are deemed acceptable by the Committee, your Board’s finding today would allow subsequent Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals to designate these fixtures by specific brand name per Public Contract Code Section 3400 (c) 2.   San Jose City College is expected to be selecting exterior lighting in the near future that your Board will be asked to make a similar finding and add to the table of products listed below.
	 
Presently, it is recommended that the materials and products listed in the table below be allowed to be designated by specific brand or trade name, with substituted products not allowed, in Invitations for Bids or Requests for Proposals involving District facilities.  The current development of the District Design Standards may result in future recommendations to the Board to add materials, products, things or services that meet the criteria established in Public Contract Code Section 3400 to this list.

items.item_details:
In development of the 2025 Facilities Master Plan (FMP) for Evergreen Valley College (EVC), data related to the Evergreen Fault adjacent to campus was updated and depicted on the FMP site plan.  That data and plan identified portions of the EVC campus to be within a State-designated Alquist-Priolo Special Study Zone.  California Geologic Survey Publication 42, “Fault Rupture Hazard Zones in California” requires designation of an area within 50 feet of an active fault as a no-build zone.  This requirement places the Roble and Acacia buildings at EVC within this no-build zone.
	 
Following this identification in November 2011, Evergreen Valley College considered various actions for the replacement or relocation of the affected buildings.  One consideration was to apply for state funding for both buildings, but there was no state funding for buildings and a state-wide bond would have been necessary to establish that funding.  This path, and the inability to commence design and construction until funding was identified, would have prevented EVC from taking any major action until at least 2015.  A second choice was to forego state funding completely and build complete replacement buildings under the Bond.  Under this scenario the new buildings would have been available for occupancy in early 2016, but would have depleted funds for other important aspects of the Facility Master Plan.  A third option was to address the Acacia Building and start its replacement buildings (South Campus and Automotive Technology) and to request state funding on replacing the Roble Building.  This would provide replacement for Acacia in 2016 and for Roble in 2018.  This third choice was the selected option, and funding requests for the Engineering/Applied Technology were submitted through an Initial Project Proposal (IPP) in July 2012 and a Final Project Proposal (FPP) in July 2013.  
	 
At the same time, numerous actions were required of the District and the Board by the Education Code and Field Act as a result of the fault identification.  At its November 12, 2013 meeting the Board received information that updated the status of those required actions. (See attached presentation from that meeting.)  These included:
Prepare cost estimates to address replacement or relocation of affected buildings – performed in June 2011 and Oct 2013
Notify the State and apply for funding – notified in July 2012 and July 2013
Board notification – notified in November 2011 and November 2013
Engineering study of building safety – completed by Thornton Tomasetti in October 2013
	 
The key elements from that November 12, 2013 presentation were a finding that Roble and Acacia are, from an engineering standpoint, considered unsafe.  (The definition of “unsafe” is driven by Education Code 81162.)  Further, legal counsel has stated that, “The provisions of the Education Code … and the Field Act itself, do not require the District to stop using existing school buildings which have, by virtue of new information, been determined to be unsafe in the event of earthquake.”  And the engineers have noted that “There is no code or law in effect that mandates that buildings designed and constructed according to a previous version of the code need to be brought into conformance with the current code, provided that there is no change in use or alteration that includes a significant increase in load or decrease in structural capacity. So despite the fact that the Acacia and Roble Clusters do not meet current code, continued use of these buildings is allowed by code…..”
	 
Since the November 12, 2013 Board meeting, the college has presented the circumstances to the faculty and staff through participatory governance and campus forums, and to student government.  The engineer’s report, the schedules for retrofit and new building construction, and the opinions of legal counsel were all presented and discussed.  The various options were presented and additional options identified. At the conclusion of these meetings, with all considerations made, it is the consensus of the College and the President’s recommendation that Roble and Acacia remain in service without modification.  The South Campus and Automotive Technology projects will commence construction in 2014, which will provide replacement space for the majority of sections now using Acacia.  The college will continue pursuit of supportive State funding for the Engineering & Technology project, which will be constructed on the site of Roble.  Should State funding not materialize, the college will develop alternative plans to continue toward development of that building.
	 
	 
At the February 25, 2014 Board meeting the Board requested information regarding accessibility compliance of the buildings. While the condition of each building's accessibility is not specifically known as no recent studies have been performed, known ADA issues have been addressed by the College in previous years and elevators are in operation for floor-to-floor access.  The accessibility around the buildings has been evaluated through the site assessment and master planning recently accomplished and the College is undertaking efforts to address those findings.  
	 
Additionally information was requested on February 25, 2014 regarding which planned projects might be affected by use of funds to strengthen both buildings (Option 2).  Should the strengthening of Roble and Acacia be directed, funding will be drawn from the college's Measure G-2010 funds currently designated for building demolition and from various other projects that are focused on 1) addressing mechanical and electrical deficiencies on campus, 2) providing students new classroom furniture and 3) addressing interior and exterior environmental conditions across the campus.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the recommendation by Evergreen Valley College (EVC), based on review of the structural study and evaluations by EVC participatory governance groups, that Roble and Acacia remain in service without modification during development of South Campus, Automotive Technology and Engineering / Applied Technology.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 presents their Reopener Proposal with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District for 2013-2014.  The California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 will provide the Articles to be negotiated for 2013-2014, during the board meeting.
	 
CSEA respectfully submits the following bargaining proposals:
	 
Article 3 – Union Rights
CSEA has an interest in eliminating language concerning number of bargaining team members.
	 
Article 6 - Salary
CSEA has an interest in a fair and equitable pay increase.  CSEA has an interest in modifying the Campus Police retirement system from CalPERS to CalPERS Saftey.  CSEA has an interest to modify Police Officer shift rotation to address the need to shift selection by seniority.
	 
Article 8 – Work Schedule
CSEA has an interest to add language that would allow for an alternate work schedule during the summer months.
	 
Article 21 – Retirement Benefits
CSEA has an interest in a permanent “Bridge Plan” for eligible CSEA bargaining unit members.
	 
Article 23 – Reclassification
CSEA has an interest in adding an appeal process.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present CSEA’s contract reopener proposal for 2013-2014, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the April 8, 2014 Board meeting.
